page.title: 20The Dunmow Flitch (Modern)
page.content: In order to win the Flitch - a side of bacon - the married couple have to prove to a jury that they have not had a cross word for a year and a day. There is a judge, prosecuting council for the bacon and defence council, all of whom are usually well-known personalities such as Claire Rayner, an 'agony aunt' for the Daily Mirror, who will attract large crowds. The jury is made up of six men and six women who have to be single and from the neighbourhood. Although these proceedings are light hearted they follow the pattern of a normal court case. The Flitch is presented to the winning couples in a ceremony held outside the Old Town Hall in the late evening. In 1984 three of the four couples on trial won their case and were awarded their flitch of bacon.
